Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SI2-SSI: The Community-Driven Big-CZ Software System for Integration and Analysis of Bio- and Geoscience Data in the Critical Zone

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Critical Zone (CZ) science community takes as its charge the effort to integrate theory, models and data from the multitude of disciplines collectively studying processes on the Earth's surface. The Critical Zone is Earth's permeable near-surface layer - from the atmosphere at the vegetation's canopy to the lower boundary of actively circulating groundwaters. The Critical Zone was a term coined by the National Research Council's Basic Research Opportunities in the Earth Sciences (BROES) Report (2001) to highlight the imperative for a new approach to thoroughly multi-disciplinary research on the zone of the Earth?s surface that is critical to sustaining terrestrial life on our planet. In January 2013, 103 members of the CZ community met for the CZ-EarthCube Domain Workshop (NSF Award #1252238) to prioritize the CZ community's key science drivers, key computational and information technology ("cyber") challenges and key cyber needs. They identified that the central scientific challenge of the critical zone science community is to develop a "grand unifying theory" of the critical zone through a theory-model-data fusion approach. Work participants unanimously described that the key missing need of this approach was a future cyberinfrastructure for seamless 4D visual exploration of the integrated knowledge (data, model outputs and interpolations) from all the bio and geoscience disciplines relevant to critical zone structure and function, similar to today?s ability to easily explore historical satellite imagery and photographs of the earth's surface using Google Earth. This project takes the first "BiG" steps toward answering that need.

The overall goal of this project is to co-develop with the CZ science and broader community, including natural resource managers and stakeholders, a web-based integration and visualization environment for joint analysis of cross-scale bio and geoscience processes in the critical zone (BiG CZ), spanning experimental and observational designs. Our Project Objectives are to: (1) Engage the CZ and broader community to co-develop and deploy the BiG CZ software stack; (2) Develop the BiG CZ Portal web application for intuitive, high-performance map-based discovery, visualization, access and publication of data by scientists, resource managers, educators and the general public; (3) Develop the BiG CZ Toolbox to enable cyber-savvy CZ scientists to access BiG CZ Application Programming Interfaces (APIs); and (4) Develop the BiG CZ Central software stack to bridge data systems developed for multiple critical zone domains into a single metadata catalog. The entire BiG CZ Software system will be developed on public repositories as a modular suite of fully open source software projects. It will be built around a new Observations Data Model Version 2.0 (ODM2) that is being developed by members of the BiG CZ project team, with community input, under separate funding (NSF Award #1224638).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the coupled processes of natural systems requires data from multiple disciplines. This is especially true in terrestrial environments, where interactions between living organisms, water, soil, and rock materials are most complex and intense. Studying such areas, referred to as the Earth’s Critical Zone requires comprehensive data collection and specialized software and data frameworks enabling sharing and integration of information and knowledge from different geoscience disciplines. Critical zone scientists from 16 bio- and geoscience disciplines are at the front line of efforts to effectively compile and use the "dark data in the long tail" of Earth science and integrate that data with the "Big Data" produced by hydrologists, atmospheric scientists, geospatial modelers, and molecular biologists. This project was motivated by strong and nearly unanimous needs expressed at the EarthCube End-User Domain workshop for Critical Zone Science, hosted by our team in Jan. 2013.

The BiG-CZ Data Scientific Software Integration project addressed this central challenge by integrating an opensource software stack specifically designed to solve the challenges of managing, sharing, analyzing and integrating diverse data from Biological and Geological (BiG) disciplines for Critical Zone (CZ) science.The result is an innovative, operational software environment that allows scientists from multiple domains but also resource managers, citizen-scientist volunteers, educators, students, the media and the general public to efficiently publish, find, integrate, analyze and visualize diverse terrestrial data.

BiG-CZ Data software (http://bigcz.org) is built upon the Observations Data Model v2.0 (ODM2,http://ODM2.org), a new information model aimed at facilitating greater interoperability across scientific disciplines and domain cyberinfrastructures that serve such diverse data as: hydrological time series, soil and sediment geochemistry, biodiversity surveys, oceanographic sensor profiles, multidimensional spectra, and more (Horsburgh et al. 2016? Hsu et al. 2017). ODM2 provided a common structure and vocabulary for describing and integrating these diverse data types, which is necessary to support many scientific analyses that use CZ data, and facilitated the development of software designed for this purpose.

Key project accomplishments include enhancement and development of a software stack built on ODM2, from the development of underlying database structures to web services and registries that support discovery and access to CZ data to advanced visualization and analysis tools that demonstrate the use of these data in scientific research.

We engaged the CZ and broader community, through three community workshops in the first project years, over 16 presentations at scientific conferences, and numerous integrations with other software systems to leverage previous NSF and other investments. Community input from these workshops drove our development. The BiG-CZ Data and ODM2 software collection were showcased at our capstone 2017 BiG-CZ/ ODM2 Hands-On Workshop, held November 15-16, 2017, at University of California Riverside. The complete content of the workshop, including slides, walkthrough examples, and installation packages, is available at https://github.com/BiGCZ/bigcz_wshp2017.

We launched the BiG-CZ Data Portal (https://portal.bigcz.org/), which lets users query data using several advanced user interfaces, visualize the results, and perform geospatial data analysis. This portal images (1 of 6) combines capabilities of several search engines, which have been developed through separate projects funded by the NSF. As a result, users can more confidently find the data they need using text search as well as temporal and spatial queries, retrieve and integrate the data into their research workflows. New users can try it out or read more at http://bigcz.org/portal.html.

We delivered the BiG-CZ Data Toolbox (http://bigcz.org/toolbox.html), which represents a collection of Python programs with a well-defined application programming interface, along with examples of data access and analysis in R, making it easier for researchers to analyze data and also contribute their own data to a common framework. We packaged the BiG-CZ Data Toolbox for easy installation on a personal computer via a Conda package (https://anaconda.org/odm2). We also developed hands-on tutorials using JupyterNotebooks in Python and R (https://github.com/BiGCZ/bigcz_wshp2017).

We implemented the BiG-CZ Data Catalog (http://bigcz.org/catalog.html) by developing a single, unified free-text search interface at https://portal.bigcz.org/ for three diverse and complementary data catalogs, CINERGI, HydroShare and CUAHSI Water Data Center, demonstrating how BiG-CZ software can make it easier for scientists to discover and retrieve data from multiple disparate repositories. Additionally, we developed two complementary RESTful web service APIs for the ODM2 database and software system.

In addition to its research and development mission, the project engaged a number of young researchers and students in the development and testing of the project’s software components, and in using the system for their own analysis.

All software developed by the project is openly available for reuse in public, open-source code repositories on GitHub at https://github.com/BiG-CZ, https://github.com/ODM2, and https://github.com/wikiwatershed.
